channel.title: Changkhui: Changkhui in English
channel.itunes:subtitle: What Thais Think
channel.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
channel.itunes:summary: This podcast is a translation of our Thai podcasts. Changkhui podcasts started in August 2006 and by March 2007 Changkhui is offering 10 podcasts. Most of these are on a weekly basis. Because much of this will be interesting to a non-Thai audience our translations provide an avenue for non-Thais to gain knowledge of the way Thai people think and their concerns. We also want to make available news that is published in smaller and regional media but does not appear in the Bangkok Post or The Nation.
channel.description: This podcast is a translation of our Thai podcasts. Changkhui podcasts started in August 2006 and by March 2007 Changkhui is offering 10 podcasts. Most of these are on a weekly basis. Because much of this will be interesting to a non-Thai audience our translations provide an avenue for non-Thais to gain knowledge of the way Thai people think and their concerns. We also want to make available news that is published in smaller and regional media but does not appear in the Bangkok Post or The Nation.

item.title: CIE: 10. Life Goes On (in Bangkok)
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: @BkkGreg, @Thai101 and Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:summary: A special episode to show that we all still lived after the riots during May 17 - 21, 2010. Rikker (@Thai101), Greg (@BkkGreg) and me (@hongsyok) shared our expeience during the riots and expressed our views on the effects it made on us as we all lived and were also in Bangkok during the time.

item.title: CIE: 9. Hosting a Student by Diane
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: @CuriosityBlue, @MobSK128 and Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:summary: Mob, a guest on Changkhui last year, was an AFS exchange student to Alaska, USA, during July 2008 - July 2009. In April 2010, about 10 months after he came back, his host parents came over to visit him in Bangkok. It must have been an awesome experience, since they arrived during the Red-shirt movement at Ratchprasong intersection. On this episode, we talked to both Diane, the host mother, and Mob to share their life experience in hosting an exchange student.

item.title: CIE: 8. Top 10 Thai Movies of 2009 by @WiseKwai
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: @wisekwai, @Thai101 and Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:summary: The same gang from episode 7 regrouped. This time, we took another entry from @WiseKwai blog, http://thaifilmjournal.blogspot.com/2010/01/top-10-thai-films-of-2009.html, and made an episode out of it. As usual for a company of three that one would steer away from a topic and one would need to pull him or her back, thus, a 90-minute episode. A few of the movies were quite hard to find through normal Thai movies distribution. Oddly enough, those in overseas may have a better chance of finding them than we who live in Thailand.

item.title: CIE: 7. Top 10 Thai Movies of the Past Decade by WiseKwai
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: @wisekwai, @Thai101 and Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:summary: It's been over a year since we had an episode in English. This time, we have a listener who pulled an interesting subject to contribute to Changkhui. Rikker Dockum, our long-time listener, asked if Curtis, AKA @wisekwai, if he would like to share what he wrote on his blog and talk about it. His blog was http://thaifilmjournal.blogspot.com/2009/12/top-10-thai-films-of-2000s.html and the entry we talked about was the Thai Top 10 of the 2000s. It's was even more interesting when we knew that he could not speak or read Thai, but managed to enjoy it via english subtitles.

item.title: Changkhui in English: 6. How Many I's are there in Thai?
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: Felix Loesch and Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:summary: From a guest, we asked if Felix would like to try hosting a program. Because he was quite fluent in Thai so we tried a Thai lesson. This time, it's about how many different ways of saying I in Thai. In English, as we all know it, there is only one I. In this episode, we came up with 10 different ways of I in Thai.

item.title: Changkhui in English: 5. Pizza Boy
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: Felix Loesch and Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:summary: We had a guest on this episode. Felix was our fan, who lived in Pangan Island. He was the one who paid Passakorn a visit during his stop in Bangkok a month ago. We both read an recommended topic in Pantip.Com and shared comments on this episode. Thank you Felix and hope to host an episode with you again, sometime.

item.title: Changkhui in English 4: Lost in Translation
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: David Aldridge and Passakorn
item.itunes:summary: Having attending a presentation recently by overseas company, it trigged us to think of the topic. All these presentations could have been much better if they paid more attention on customers background and, also, the Thai culture. We invited our friend, David B. Aldridge to share his experience in dealing with the situation as both a listener and a presenter. We luckily caught him just a few days before he went overseas.
item.itunes:keywords: Thai Podcast, Thai, David Aldridge, Thai Podcast in English

item.title: Changkhui in English 3: Working with Thai by David Aldridge
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: David Aldridge and Passakorn
item.itunes:summary: Passakorn managed to get a classmate to join a session in Changkhui, he was David Aldridge. He had been in Thailand for some time, had been with a multi-national firm and currently with a Thai firm. He gave us his 2cents on interviewing Thai and working with Thai. We touched a little bit on software pricing in Thailand.
item.itunes:keywords: Thai Podcast, Thai, David Aldridge, Thai Podcast in English

item.title: Changkhui in English 2: Sigve Brekke
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: Sigve Brekke and Passakorn
item.itunes:summary: After some relatively easy correspondence, we managed to have a discussion with Sigve Brekke, the CEO of DTAC. We talked about his view on various issues, such as his perception of the use of Internet on mobile phones, Thai cultures, etc. I am sure some of you must have read some these stuffs from his interview elsewhere. But believe me, it's always different when you actually hear it from the source himself. I would have to apologize for the sound quality, though, there were quite a few humming and echoing sounds.
item.itunes:keywords: Thai Podcast, Thai, Sigve Brekke, DTAC, Thai Podcast in English

item.title: Changkhui in English 1: Jatukarm Ramathep
item.itunes:author: Passakorn Hongsyok
item.itunes:subtitle: Worawat and Passakorn
item.itunes:summary: We explained our intent for this podcast, and, also, a brief overview of what our 10 podcasts cover. And, in the 2nd half, we covered a little bit about Jatukam Ramathep, which we covered Changkhui and Boy City Chan podcast.
item.itunes:keywords: Thai Podcast, Thai, Jatukam Ramathep, Thai Podcast in English
